title: Friends reboot: Breaking Bad's El Camino doesn’t mean we need reunion
text:
El Camino is only going to encourage the Friends reboot conversation (Picture: Getty/Netflix)

With the success of Breaking Bad’s reboot El Camino, I suspect fans of Friends are drafting up their argument for a similar, Netflix-style reunion.

Because another week, another call for Friends to return, right?

I’m afraid I’m here to poo-poo over those plans; just because one reboot managed to not pale in comparison to its series predecessor does not mean they all will.

Despite it being made quite clear there is no Friends film reboot on the horizon, I hazard a guess the return of Jesse Pinkman and Walter White is only enthusing the Friends fans more so.

Baiting them.

Egging them on.

Encouraging them to merge on Netflix/Amazon/Sky/[insert another reboot-friendly platform here]’s grounds, pitchforks blazing and demand Ross and Rachel return.

There’s a keen difference between El Camino and any potential Friends return, though: Unlike Breaking Bad, Friends ended with everything wrapped up in a neat little package.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Chandler and Monica had their babies, Ross and Rachel reunited, Phoebe was happy with Mike, Joey was content in himself and how he was doooin’. They were leaving that ridiculous apartment and we knew they wouldn’t return. In our minds, we knew they’d be there for us when the rain started to fall, but we didn’t need it reiterated in a reboot.

We sort of needed to know where Jesse was (Picture: Ben Rothstein / Netflix)

And up until quite recently, we were so fine with that.

So why are we now hellbent on bringing them back, with the actors who have moved on in the 15 years since plagued by questions on its potential return week after week.

That picture Jennifer Aniston posted to Instagram with the rest of the cast didn’t help things.

Just because other franchises are rebooting around it, whether rightly or wrongly, it doesn’t mean Friends has to.

El Camino was a welcome accoutrement to Breaking Bad’s finale. We knew where Walt (Bryan Cranston) ended up (sad face) but when it came to Jesse (Aaron Paul), the spinoff served to continue his story. And it worked brilliantly. It wasn’t necessary, but it was welcome.

When it comes to Friends, there is nothing necessary about a reboot other than to satisfy our own selfish minds, unimaginative in coming to our own conclusions on where the characters are in 2019.

El Camino brought back characters that had more to tell, the story more to show; we truly didn’t know where Jesse ended up immediately after the final scene. With the cast of Friends, we don’t NEED to know where they ended up and anything that is presented to us is only going to disappoint so many anyway.

Stop trying to make a film reboot happen…it’s not going to happen (Picture: NBC Universal, Inc.)

If the writers of Game Of Thrones can’t ruddy get the finale right, what hopes do the showrunners of Friends have in creating a film that will make millions of viewers content?

Advertisement

Advertisement

After the six lead actors recently reunited, Jennifer, who played Rachel Green, was asked by Howard Stern whether they were chatting a reunion.

She said she ‘would be nothing without [the show]’, but even Jen was hesitant to confirm they were getting back together.

‘I honestly think…we would love it…there is an idea if there is a reboot of the show it won’t be even close to as good as what it was. It would ruin it,’ she said, agreeing the legacy of the show was important.

Whoop, there it is: common sense.

Jennifer’s comments come just months after Adam Sandler publicly called on her to make a ‘f***ing Friends movie’.

‘Friends was a powerhouse,’ added Adam, speaking to People. ‘Everybody on Friends is excellent, everybody likes them. America, the world loves the cast.’

This is fan-baiting at its very best, but many may argue no one should take winning film advice from Adam Sandler…

With all this talk of a Clueless reboot, Home Alone reboot, Jay And Silent Bob reboot, a flippin’ Barney reboot, the over-saturation of old classics getting the 2019 treatment is getting tired.

I’ll run the risk of having Barney ruined for me, but Friends stands to lose something a little more special if it’s brought back with a one-off film special that languishes in our mighty expectations.

Advertisement

Let’s leave it in the 00s, where it well and truly belongs.

In other news, won’t there be egg on my face if Friends makes a successful film reboot…
